message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Secure Containment Control for Multi-UAV Systems by Fixed-Time Convergent Reinforcement Learning
Paper Abstract: This article concerns the secure containment control problem for multiple autonomous aerial vehicles. The cyber attacker can manipulate control commands, resulting in containment failure in the position loop. Within a zero-sum graphical game framework, secure containment controllers and malicious attackers are regarded as game players, and the attack-defense process is recast as a min-max optimization problem. Acquiring optimal distributed secure control policies requires solving the game-related Hamilton-Jacobi-Isaacs (HJI) equations. Based on the critic-only neural network (NN) structure, the reinforcement learning (RL) method is employed in solving coupled HJI equations. The fixed-time convergence technique is introduced to improve the convergence rate of RL, and the experience replay mechanism is utilized to relax the persistence of excitation condition. The associated NN convergence and closed-loop stability are analyzed. In the attitude loop, the optimal feedback control law is obtained by solving Hamilton-Jacobi-Bellman equations using the fixed-time convergent RL method. The simulation example and the quadrotor experiment are given to show the effectiveness of the proposed scheme.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Web search results for query: "Quadrotor"

Links: [{"title":"Quadcopter - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quadcopter"},{"title":"Talk:Quadcopter - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Quadrotor"},{"title":"Asisguard Songar - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Asisguard_Songar"},{"title":"Category:Quadrotors - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Quadrotors"},{"title":"Tsinghua Throne - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tsinghua_Throne"},{"title":"MikroKopter - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MikroKopter"}]

Here are the search results for "Quadrotor":

## Overview

A quadcopter, also called quadrocopter, or quadrotor is a type of helicopter or multicopter that has four rotors.(no content)Although quadrotor helicopters and convertiplanes have long been flown experimentally, the configuration remained a curiosity until the arrival of the modern unmanned aerial vehicle or drone.

## How Quadrotors Work

Quadcopters generally have two rotors spinning clockwise (CW) and two counterclockwise (CCW), with flight control provided by independent variation of the speed and hence lift and torque of each rotor.(no content)Pitch and roll are controlled by varying the net centre of thrust, with yaw controlled by varying the net torque.

## Key Differences from Traditional Helicopters

Unlike conventional helicopters, quadcopters do not usually have cyclic pitch control, in which the angle of the blades varies dynamically as they turn around the rotor hub.

## Modern Applications

The small size and low inertia of drones allows use of a particularly simple flight control system, which has greatly increased the practicality of the small quadrotor in this application.

## Reinforcement Learning - Search Results

I've completed a web search for "Reinforcement Learning". Here's what I found:

### Definition
Reinforcement learning (RL) is concerned with how an intelligent agent should take actions in a dynamic environment in order to maximize a reward signal.(no content)Reinforcement learning is one of the three basic machine learning paradigms, alongside supervised learning and unsupervised learning.

### Key Concepts
While supervised learning and unsupervised learning algorithms respectively attempt to discover patterns in labeled and unlabeled data, reinforcement learning involves training an agent through interactions with its environment.(no content)To learn to maximize rewards from these interactions, the agent makes decisions between trying new actions to learn more about the environment (exploration), or using current knowledge of the environment to take the best action (exploitation). The search for the optimal balance between these two strategies is known as the exploration–exploitation dilemma.

### Applications
It has been applied successfully to various problems, including energy storage, robot control, photovoltaic generators, backgammon, checkers, Go (AlphaGo), and autonomous driving systems.

### Why It's Powerful
Two elements make reinforcement learning powerful: the use of samples to optimize performance, and the use of function approximation to deal with large environments.

The search results cover various aspects of RL, including deep reinforcement learning, multi-agent RL, Q-learning algorithms, and related techniques like reinforcement learning from human feedback (RLHF).

Links: [{"title":"Hamilton–Jacobi–Bellman equation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hamilton–Jacobi–Bellman_equation"},{"title":"Hamilton–Jacobi equation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hamilton–Jacobi_equation"},{"title":"Bellman equation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bellman_equation"},{"title":"Talk:Hamilton–Jacobi–Bellman equation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Hamilton–Jacobi–Bellman_equation"},{"title":"Richard E. Bellman - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Richard_Bellman"},{"title":"Pontryagin's maximum principle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pontryagin's_maximum_principle"},{"title":"HJB - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/?redirect=no&title=HJB"},{"title":"Dynamic programming - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dynamic_programming"},{"title":"Bellman - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bellman"},{"title":"Hamilton–Jacobi–Einstein equation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hamilton%E2%80%93Jacobi%E2%80%93Einstein_equation"}]

## Hamilton-Jacobi-Bellman Equation

The Hamilton-Jacobi-Bellman (HJB) equation is a nonlinear partial differential equation that provides necessary and sufficient conditions for optimality of a control with respect to a loss function.

### Purpose and Solution

Its solution is the value function of the optimal control problem which, once known, can be used to obtain the optimal control by taking the maximizer (or minimizer) of the Hamiltonian involved in the HJB equation.

### Historical Background

The equation is a result of the theory of dynamic programming which was pioneered in the 1950s by Richard Bellman and coworkers.(no content)The connection to the Hamilton–Jacobi equation from classical physics was first drawn by Rudolf Kálmán.

### Variants and Applications

In discrete-time problems, the analogous difference equation is usually referred to as the Bellman equation.(no content)It can be generalized to stochastic systems, in which case the HJB equation is a second-order elliptic partial differential equation.

### Computational Challenges

A major drawback is that the HJB equation admits classical solutions only for a sufficiently smooth value function, which is not guaranteed in most situations. Instead, the notion of a viscosity solution is required, in which conventional derivatives are replaced by (set-valued) subderivatives.

Bellman - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Richard_Bellman"},{"title":"Pontryagin's maximum principle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pontryagin's_maximum_principle"},{"title":"HJB - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/?redirect=no&title=HJB"},{"title":"Dynamic programming - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dynamic_programming"},{"title":"Bellman - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bellman"},{"title":"Hamilton–Jacobi–Einstein equation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hamilton%E2%80%93Jacobi%E2%80%93Einstein_equation"}]

## Hamilton-Jacobi-Bellman Equation

The Hamilton-Jacobi-Bellman (HJB) equation is a nonlinear partial differential equation that provides necessary and sufficient conditions for optimality of a control with respect to a loss function.

### Purpose and Solution

Its solution is the value function of the optimal control problem which, once known, can be used to obtain the optimal control by taking the maximizer (or minimizer) of the Hamiltonian involved in the HJB equation.

### Historical Background

The equation is a result of the theory of dynamic programming which was pioneered in the 1950s by Richard Bellman and coworkers.(no content)The connection to the Hamilton–Jacobi equation from classical physics was first drawn by Rudolf Kálmán.

### Variants and Applications

In discrete-time problems, the analogous difference equation is usually referred to as the Bellman equation.(no content)It can be generalized to stochastic systems, in which case the HJB equation is a second-order elliptic partial differential equation.

### Computational Challenges

A major drawback is that the HJB equation admits classical solutions only for a sufficiently smooth value function, which is not guaranteed in most situations. Instead, the notion of a viscosity solution is required, in which conventional derivatives are replaced by (set-valued) subderivatives.

I've performed a web search for "Neural Network" and found comprehensive information about this topic. Here's a summary of the key findings:

## Overview

A neural network consists of connected units or nodes called artificial neurons, which loosely model the neurons in the brain.(no content)In machine learning, a neural network is an artificial mathematical model used to approximate nonlinear functions.

## Structure and Layers

Signals travel from the first layer (the input layer) to the last layer (the output layer), possibly passing through multiple intermediate layers (hidden layers).(no content)A network is typically called a deep neural network if it has at least two hidden layers.

## Applications

Neural networks are used to solve problems in artificial intelligence, and have thereby found applications in many disciplines, including predictive modeling, adaptive control, facial recognition, handwriting recognition, general game playing, and generative AI.

## Training

Neural networks are typically trained through empirical risk minimization, which is based on the idea of optimizing the network's parameters to minimize the difference, or empirical risk, between the predicted output and the actual target values in a given dataset.(no content)Gradient-based methods such as backpropagation are usually used to estimate the parameters of the network.

## History

Today's deep neural networks are based on early work in statistics over 200 years ago. The search results also show that Frank Rosenblatt and McCulloch & Pitts made significant early contributions to neural network development.

Here are the search results for "Game Theory":

## Overview

Game theory is the study of mathematical models of strategic interactions.(no content)It has applications in many fields of social science, and is used extensively in economics, logic, systems science and computer science.(no content)It is now an umbrella term for the science of rational decision making in humans, animals, and computers.

## History

Modern game theory began with the idea of mixed-strategy equilibria in two-person zero-sum games and its proof by John von Neumann.(no content)His paper was followed by Theory of Games and Economic Behavior (1944), co-written with Oskar Morgenstern, which considered cooperative games of several players.(no content)Initially, game theory addressed two-person zero-sum games, in which a participant's gains or losses are exactly balanced by the losses and gains of the other participant. In the 1950s, it was extended to the study of non zero-sum games, and was eventually applied to a wide range of behavioral relations.

## Key Concepts

Nash's most famous contribution to game theory is the concept of the Nash equilibrium, which is a solution concept for non-cooperative games, published in 1951. A Nash equilibrium is a set of strategies, one for each player, such that no player can improve their payoff by unilaterally changing their strategy.(no content)Cooperative games are often analyzed through the framework of cooperative game theory, which focuses on predicting which coalitions will form, the joint actions that groups take, and the resulting collective payoffs.

## Recognition

John Maynard Smith was awarded the Crafoord Prize for his application of evolutionary game theory in 1999, and fifteen game theorists have won the Nobel Prize in economics as of 2020, including most recently Paul Milgrom and Robert B. Wilson.

Based on the web search results, here's what I found about the Hamilton-Jacobi-Isaacs equation:

The Hamilton-Jacobi-Isaacs equation arises in differential games applications and is used with viscosity solution concepts. This equation is a natural extension of similar equations used in control theory and optimization.

The Hamilton-Jacobi-Isaacs equation belongs to a family of related equations:

- The Hamilton-Jacobi-Bellman (HJB) equation is a nonlinear partial differential equation that provides necessary and sufficient conditions for optimality of a control with respect to a loss function, and its solution is the value function of the optimal control problem.

- The Hamilton-Jacobi-Isaacs equation extends this framework to game-theoretic settings where multiple players (or adversaries) have conflicting objectives, rather than the single-controller case of the HJB equation.

- Several notions of generalized solutions have been developed, including viscosity solution and minimax solution, which are particularly important for these equations since the HJB equation does not have a classical (smooth) solution in the general case.

The Hamilton-Jacobi-Isaacs equation is fundamentally important in differential game theory, optimal control, and related fields where one needs to analyze strategic interactions between competing agents.

Links: [{"title":"Hamilton–Jacobi equation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hamilton–Jacobi_equation"},{"title":"Hamilton–Jacobi–Bellman equation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hamilton–Jacobi–Bellman_equation"},{"title":"Viscosity solution - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Viscosity_solution"},{"title":"Hamilton–Jacobi–Einstein equation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hamilton–Jacobi–Einstein_equation"},{"title":"Hamiltonian mechanics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hamiltonian_mechanics"},{"title":"Geodesics as Hamiltonian flows - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Geodesics_as_Hamiltonian_flows"},{"title":"List of things named after Carl Gustav Jacob Jacobi - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_things_named_after_Carl_Gustav_Jacob_Jacobi"},{"title":"Canonical transformation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Canonical_transformation"},{"title":"Classical central-force problem - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Classical_central-force_problem"},{"title":"Jacobi's formula - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jacobi's_formula"}]

Based on the web search results, here's what I found about the Hamilton-Jacobi-Isaacs equation:

The Hamilton-Jacobi-Isaacs equation arises in differential games applications and is used with viscosity solution concepts. This equation is a natural extension of similar equations used in control theory and optimization.

The Hamilton-Jacobi-Isaacs equation belongs to a family of related equations:

- The Hamilton-Jacobi-Bellman (HJB) equation is a nonlinear partial differential equation that provides necessary and sufficient conditions for optimality of a control with respect to a loss function, and its solution is the value function of the optimal control problem.

- The Hamilton-Jacobi-Isaacs equation extends this framework to game-theoretic settings where multiple players (or adversaries) have conflicting objectives, rather than the single-controller case of the HJB equation.

- Several notions of generalized solutions have been developed, including viscosity solution and minimax solution, which are particularly important for these equations since the HJB equation does not have a classical (smooth) solution in the general case.

The Hamilton-Jacobi-Isaacs equation is fundamentally important in differential game theory, optimal control, and related fields where one needs to analyze strategic interactions between competing agents.

Web search results for query: "Experience replay"

Links: [{"title":"Hippocampal replay - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hippocampal_replay"},{"title":"Session replay - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Session_replay"},{"title":"Game replay - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Replay_review"},{"title":"Q-learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Q-learning"},{"title":"Virtual replay - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Virtual_replay"},{"title":"Replay (Grimwood novel) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Replay_(Grimwood_novel)"},{"title":"Instant replay - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Instant_replay"},{"title":"Experience - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Experience"},{"title":"Tealeaf - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tealeaf"},{"title":"Rare Replay - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rare_Replay"}]

Based on the search results, "experience replay" has multiple meanings depending on the context:

## Machine Learning/Reinforcement Learning

In the context of reinforcement learning algorithms like Q-learning, experience replay is a biologically inspired mechanism that uses a random sample of prior actions instead of the most recent action to proceed, which removes correlations in the observation sequence and smooths changes in the data distribution.

## Neuroscience

In neuroscience, during sleep or awake rest, replay refers to the re-occurrence of a sequence of cell activations that also occurred during activity, but the replay has a much faster time scale.(no content)Hippocampal replay has been proposed to support memory consolidation and the construction of internal "cognitive maps" of space and events, and more recent computational and behavioral work suggests that replay may also contribute to planning and flexible decision making by allowing prospective sequences of states or actions to be evaluated before they are executed.

The search results also showed related concepts like session replay (for web/mobile analytics), instant replay (in sports), and virtual replay (3D animations of sporting events), but these are distinct from the primary meaning of "experience replay" in machine learning and neuroscience.

Web search results for query: "Unmanned aerial vehicle"

Links: [{"title":"Unmanned aerial vehicle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unmanned_aerial_vehicle"},{"title":"List of unmanned aerial vehicles - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_unmanned_aerial_vehicles"},{"title":"History of unmanned aerial vehicles - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_unmanned_aerial_vehicles"},{"title":"Unmanned combat aerial vehicle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unmanned_combat_aerial_vehicle"},{"title":"Unmanned aerial vehicles in the United States military - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unmanned_aerial_vehicles_in_the_United_States_military"},{"title":"412th Unmanned Aerial Vehicle Regiment (Ukraine) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/412th_Unmanned_Aerial_Vehicle_Regiment_(Ukraine)"},{"title":"List of unmanned aerial vehicle applications - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_unmanned_aerial_vehicle_applications"},{"title":"Uncrewed vehicle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unmanned_vehicle"},{"title":"Category:Unmanned aerial vehicle manufacturers of the United States - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Unmanned_aerial_vehicle_manufacturers_of_the_United_States"},{"title":"List of unmanned aerial vehicle-related incidents - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_unmanned_aerial_vehicle-related_incidents"}]

Here's what I found about unmanned aerial vehicles:

## Definition and Basic Characteristics

An unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) or unmanned aircraft system (UAS), commonly known as a drone, is an aircraft with no human pilot, crew, or passengers on board, but rather is controlled remotely or is autonomous.(no content)UAVs include both autonomous drones and remotely piloted vehicles (RPVs), and a UAV is capable of controlled, sustained level flight and is powered by a jet, reciprocating, or electric engine.

## History

The earliest recorded use of an unmanned aerial vehicle for warfighting occurred in July 1849, with Austrian forces besieging Venice attempting to launch some 200 incendiary balloons at the besieged city.(no content)The Spanish engineer Leonardo Torres Quevedo introduced a radio-based control-system called the Telekino at the Paris Academy of Science in 1903, as a way of testing airships without risking human life.

## Modern Applications

Unmanned aerial vehicles are used across the world for civilian, commercial, as well as military applications. Examples include crop dusting in Japan using Yamaha's unmanned helicopters since 1987, and in the U.S. for crop spraying, as well as aerial crop surveys, aerial photography, search and rescue, and inspection of power lines and pipelines.

## Consumer Market Growth

In 2013, DJI released the first model of the Phantom drone at $629, which was considered one of the most influential consumer drone products ever made.

Web search results for query: "Zero-sum game"

Links: [{"title":"Zero-sum game - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zero-sum_game"},{"title":"Zero-sum thinking - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zero-sum_thinking"},{"title":"Game without a value - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Game_without_a_value"},{"title":"Nash equilibrium - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nash_equilibrium"},{"title":"Game theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Game_theory"},{"title":"Zermelo's theorem (game theory) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zermelo's_theorem_(game_theory)"},{"title":"Yao's principle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Randomized_algorithms_as_zero-sum_games"},{"title":"Simultaneous game - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Simultaneous_game"},{"title":"Silverman's game - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Silverman's_game"},{"title":"Non-cooperative game theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Non-cooperative_game_theory"}]

Based on the search results, here's information about zero-sum games:

## Definition

A zero-sum game is a mathematical representation in game theory and economic theory of a situation that involves two competing entities, where the result is an advantage for one side and an equivalent loss for the other.(no content)In other words, player one's gain is equivalent to player two's loss, with the result that the net improvement in benefit of the game is zero.

## Key Characteristics

Such games are distributive, not integrative; the pie cannot be enlarged by good negotiation.(no content)In zero-sum games, the total benefit goes to all players in a game, for every combination of strategies, and always adds to zero (more informally, a player benefits only at the equal expense of others).

## Common Examples

Examples of zero-sum games in daily life include games like poker, chess, sport and bridge where one person gains and another person loses, which results in a zero-net benefit for every player.(no content)In the markets and financial instruments, futures contracts and options are zero-sum games as well.

## Contrast with Non-Zero-Sum Games

In situations where one decision maker's gain (or loss) does not necessarily result in the other decision makers' loss (or gain), they are referred to as non-zero-sum. For example, a country with an excess of bananas trading with another country for their excess of apples, where both benefit from the transaction, is in a non-zero-sum situation.

## Solution Methods

Zero-sum games are most often solved with the minimax theorem which is closely related to linear programming duality, or with Nash equilibrium.

For example, a country with an excess of bananas trading with another country for their excess of apples, where both benefit from the transaction, is in a non-zero-sum situation.

## Solution Methods

Zero-sum games are most often solved with the minimax theorem which is closely related to linear programming duality, or with Nash equilibrium.

Based on the search results, here's information about zero-sum games:

## Definition

A zero-sum game is a mathematical representation in game theory and economic theory of a situation that involves two competing entities, where the result is an advantage for one side and an equivalent loss for the other.(no content)In other words, player one's gain is equivalent to player two's loss, with the result that the net improvement in benefit of the game is zero.

## Key Characteristics

Such games are distributive, not integrative; the pie cannot be enlarged by good negotiation.(no content)In zero-sum games, the total benefit goes to all players in a game, for every combination of strategies, and always adds to zero (more informally, a player benefits only at the equal expense of others).

## Common Examples

Examples of zero-sum games in daily life include games like poker, chess, sport and bridge where one person gains and another person loses, which results in a zero-net benefit for every player.(no content)In the markets and financial instruments, futures contracts and options are zero-sum games as well.

## Contrast with Non-Zero-Sum Games

In situations where one decision maker's gain (or loss) does not necessarily result in the other decision makers' loss (or gain), they are referred to as non-zero-sum. For example, a country with an excess of bananas trading with another country for their excess of apples, where both benefit from the transaction, is in a non-zero-sum situation.

## Solution Methods

Zero-sum games are most often solved with the minimax theorem which is closely related to linear programming duality, or with Nash equilibrium.

I found the Wikipedia article on the Hamilton-Jacobi-Bellman equation. Here's the key information:

## Definition

The Hamilton-Jacobi-Bellman (HJB) equation is a nonlinear partial differential equation that provides necessary and sufficient conditions for optimality of a control with respect to a loss function.

## Purpose and Solution

Its solution is the value function of the optimal control problem which, once known, can be used to obtain the optimal control by taking the maximizer (or minimizer) of the Hamiltonian involved in the HJB equation.

## Historical Background

The equation is a result of the theory of dynamic programming which was pioneered in the 1950s by Richard Bellman and coworkers.(no content)The connection to the Hamilton–Jacobi equation from classical physics was first drawn by Rudolf Kálmán.

## Discrete-Time Version

In discrete-time problems, the analogous difference equation is usually referred to as the Bellman equation.

## Applications

While classical variational problems, such as the brachistochrone problem, can be solved using the Hamilton–Jacobi–Bellman equation, the method can be applied to a broader spectrum of problems.

You can access the full Wikipedia article at: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hamilton–Jacobi–Bellman_equation

1. [completed] Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. [completed] List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. [completed] For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. [completed] Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm"), relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes), entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other, wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/), relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. [completed] Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. [completed] If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

message_text:
Excellent! I have successfully completed the analysis of the paper "Secure Containment Control for Multi-UAV Systems by Fixed-Time Convergent Reinforcement Learning". Here's a summary of what was accomplished:

## Analysis Summary

**Paper Classification:** Contribution

**Key Triples Identified:** 9 entities

The analysis extracted the following technologies and methodologies from the paper:

### Methods/Concepts Used:
- **Reinforcement Learning** - Core ML method for solving optimal control policies
- **Game Theory** - Framework for attack-defense modeling
- **Zero-sum Game** - Game-theoretic framework for controller vs. attacker interactions
- **Bellman Equation** - Mathematical framework for optimal control in attitude loop
- **Neural Network** - Critic-only architecture for value function approximation

### Applications/Artifacts:
- **Unmanned Aerial Vehicle** - Application domain for secure containment control
- **Quadcopter** - Platform for experimental validation

### Novel Contributions (Proposed):
- **Optimal Control** - Novel secure containment control combining optimal control with game-theoretic RL
- **Cyber-physical Systems Security** - Defense mechanisms against control command manipulation

The validation passed successfully with all Wikipedia URLs verified and proper classification of the paper as a contribution with at least one "proposes" relation, meeting all requirements.

Sources:
- [Reinforcement learning](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reinforcement_learning)
- [Game theory](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Game_theory)
- [Zero-sum game](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zero-sum_game)
- [Neural network](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_neural_network)
- [Bellman equation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bellman_equation)
- [Unmanned aerial vehicle](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unmanned_aerial_vehicle)
- [Quadcopter](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quadcopter)
- [Optimal control](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Optimal_control)
- [Cyber-physical systems](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cyber-physical_systems)
